title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) – In the deafening roar of a playoff-level atmosphere, Gary Payton was the coolest man in the building. With the game, and perhaps the Pacific Division, hanging in the balance, “The Glove” delivered a performance for the ages, single-handedly wrestling victory from the jaws of defeat.

Payton’s historic, 42-point masterpiece was the only reason the Seattle SuperSonics escaped with a heart-stopping 98-97 victory over the rival Portland Trail Blazers. On a night where his fellow stars struggled to find their rhythm, Payton was the relentless engine, the undeniable force that refused to let his team lose.

He was brilliant from the opening tip, slicing through the Portland defense with a scorer’s precision and a point guard’s cunning. Yet, with seconds remaining and the Sonics trailing by one, it was his defense—the very trait that defines his nickname—that set the stage for the finale. Payton poked the ball free, creating a chaotic scramble that ended with him being fouled on a desperate attempt to regain possession.

With the weight of the KeyArena crowd upon him, Payton strode to the line and calmly sank two free throws, ice water in his veins, to seal the win. His 42 points were not just a season-high; they were a statement—a virtuoso performance of clutch scoring and defensive grit when his team needed it most.

While Shawn Kemp battled for his 15 points and Detlef Schrempf added a quiet 12, this night belonged solely to Gary Payton. In a brutal, back-and-forth war against a talented Blazers squad, one man stood above the fray, writing his own legendary chapter in the storied I-5 rivalry.
